introduction.title: Vietnamese Tense Markers
content: Unlike English, Vietnamese verbs never conjugate. Instead, Vietnamese uses tense markers (particles) that are placed before or after the verb to indicate when an action occurs.
The key difference: English changes the verb itself (go → went → will go), while Vietnamese keeps the verb unchanged and adds a marker word.
Many tense markers are optional when context makes the timing clear. However, using them adds clarity and emphasis.
Important: 'rồi' is the ONLY common tense marker that comes AFTER the verb. All others come BEFORE.

sections.title: Past Tense
sections.description: Markers that indicate completed actions in the past

đã.usage: Most common past tense marker. Indicates action was completed in the past.
đã.example: Tôi đã ăn cơm → I ate rice

có.usage: Emphatic past tense, similar to 'đã' but stronger. Also used for affirmation. Often used to contradict or emphasize.
có.example: Tôi có đi → I DID go

rồi.usage: Placed AFTER the verb (unique position!). Often combined with 'đã' for stronger emphasis.
rồi.example: Tôi ăn rồi → I already ate

vừa mới.usage: Indicates action was completed very recently. More formal/emphatic than 'mới' alone.
vừa mới.example: Tôi vừa mới ăn xong → I just finished eating

mới.usage: Casual form of 'vừa mới'. More common in everyday speech.
mới.example: Tôi mới ăn → I just ate

sẽ.usage: Standard future tense marker. Indicates action will happen in the future.
sẽ.example: Tôi sẽ đi học → I will go to school

sắp.usage: Indicates action is about to happen soon. Imminent future, more immediate than 'sẽ'.
sắp.example: Tôi sắp đi → I'm about to go

đang.usage: Indicates action is currently happening. Equivalent to English '-ing' form. Can combine with 'đã' for past continuous (uncommon but valid).
đang.example: Tôi đang ăn → I am eating

combinations.title: Combining Tense Markers
combinations.description: While uncommon, some tense markers can be combined for nuanced meanings

examples.notes: Very common combination. 'rồi' always comes after the verb.
Uncommon but grammatically correct. Describes ongoing action in the past.
Rare. Describes action that will be in progress at a future time.
